reviews.review_msg: Silva was extremely dedicated to seeing each and everyone of her students succeed.  All you had to do was ask - her expectations were simple.  Follower her very detailed instructions for every assignment and you will do well.  She was absolutely opinionated, but this lent to her passion for the subject and for teaching students.

She is very intimidating and expects everyone to know what she's talking about just because we are "Communication" students. Her marking scheme is weird (how do you determine 0.25 of a mark?!). You might get screwed over if she marks your assignments in a bad mood, but at least you can always redo them for a remark.
great teacher, great class.  did not see a bias.  lot's of work.
She's pretty intimidating and very opinionated.  She's someone who needs control. You will do well in her course if you see her ahead of time about all your assignments otherwise, you're screwed.

Yep, you either love her or you hate her. And I do agree that she talks about her own business too much. Since when is it a crime to be a feminist or to be gay? She is vocal about it, granted, but it only stands out because all of our other courses are taught with a "heterosexual agenda"
She makes it harder then it really is. Has a personal agenda and her way is the only way. Don't buy the text book as it is usless and expensive.
I didn't take the course, but did deal with her... and seemed very accepting of other ideas and welcoming... especially considering that mine are quite 'right' -- why do you guys think otherwise?

A little too sure of herself...Does not spend nearly enough time on what matters in the class...start EARLY on the plan, the assignments are only a small chunk of it...go check out examples from previous semesters.

Took David's intro to communications course in 1993. Big class, so hard to say how good he is as a prof.  Lectures were OK, readings no-brainer, and the workload/exams easy (just read the book, and plug in the multiple choice answers).  A'cd this course.

I took CMNS 200 with Terry in spring 2011. He was extremely helpful and went out of his way to ensure everyone was on track with their term projects. Gained a lot of practical skills and experience to take into the workforce.

The worst professor I have encountered in my four years at SFU. He is vague with his expectations but becomes extremely picky when he marks assignments. I've done three co-op workterms prior to taking this class, and I can tell you that you do NOT need this class to get a co-op. This class is a waste of money, time and energy.

Terry is by far one of the worst professors I have ever had at SFU. He is extremely vague when giving criteria for assignments, yet he is extremely critical and picky when it comes time to marking them.

I read over everyones comment about Neiman. They are entirely true. He is vague with his marking. When I requested an explanation of why he gave me this grade, he babbled contradicting nonsense as if he made it up on the spot. When I tried harder, I realized my grade would not change. He obviously already decided my fate.

Terry is a sessional grad student teaching university courses because SFU couldn't find someone interested/better. gives little to no feedback, uses unrelated examples, keeps students in the dark, tell s you you're wrong then doesn't explain why. avoid his class if you can.
Terry is a prof that gives little direction to his students, he's so vague that its hard to keep up. He invents his own "theories" which he likes to refer to, but they're pretty useless
Terry means well but is the most confusing prof I have come across. And I know I am not the only one that is confused during lectures.
